title: I dislike the new direction Ezreal's lore has taken

replies.body:
There's a lot of potential in his lore since he's the way he is for reasons, not just because.  With Zoe, she was just always like that and now her aspect mentality encourages her erratic behaviour.  With Jayce...well I don't think it's ever explained.  But with Ez, he's got a lot of problems in his background and psychological issues from growing up.   What he is makes sense.  Think of him as teenage Indiana with more personal problems, Mommy _and_ Daddy issues, and extreme lack of maturity.  When he reaches his 30s, after getting in lots of trouble and going through more personal troubles  such as seeing the true consequences of his actions (like getting severely injured or losing a loved one), he'd probably be left with his adventurous attitude minus the recklessness. If Riot is bold enough, I think they can take the character far with development and growth.   Probably won't, but we can hope.

I do feel there is a bit of trouble with the execution of it as his voiceover seems a bit too obnoxious and out of character from his lore even (not his new story though).

Jayce is the way he is because he learns much faster than others. He then cannot understand why no one is on the same page as him and gets impatient as they struggle to understand what he grasped so naturally. People then see him as arrogant because of this. I would assume this only widens the gap between him and regular people, and so his "I don't have time for stupid people" behavior was reinforced.

Jayce was always aloof and seemed to be antisocial, maybe to the point of having a social disorder. He's not a nice guy and finds people stupid compared to him, but he feels the need to protect them from their own (and other's) stupidity. The only guy he actually respected as an equal was Viktor, and now they're enemies because of it. And Viktor's got his own problems.

It's not directly explained, but there are some hints and even then he's not as bad as Zoe or Ezreal in that regard.

I've always liked Ezreal in concept, but felt he always fell short of realizing the potential of his young explorer archetype. I love new Ezreal, mostly because it addresses some of the issues I had with old Ezreal - namely that he was just too good at everything to be a compelling or interesting character. 

He was always a little arrogant, but it never reached Jayce levels of "clear character flaw," so he never really felt believable. Otherwise, he was the perfect guy. Good-looking, highly intelligent, athletic, cool, with an awesome magical gauntlet. New Ezreal seems like they were aware of the issue, and are writing him much more like a young, naive screw-up who, while talented and everything, also regularly makes silly mistakes (Forgetting to bring food during his spelunking? Bringing a single rope that he doesn't even know the length of? Carelessly leaving that artifact where civilians could touch it?), gets too wrapped up in himself to think about other people, leaps before looking, and tries way too hard to make himself look cool, only to come across as a huge dork. Instead of playing the "perfect and untouchable flawless genius" character type straight as they did with old Ezreal, they're deconstructing it and even making fun of it to an extent. I find much more compelling, especially with the addition of him wanting to be cool so that his parents come back to him giving it a sad edge. He's meant to come off as a little obnoxious, because he's trying too hard to impress. 

He is a greatly flawed kid, and I love it. He's reckless, self-absorbed, and dishonest, and I can get behind that. He's a prodigal teenager who didn't have a strong authority figure in his life, and his role models were a bunch of devil-may-care explorers. His reputation and what other people think of him is all he really has to define himself. He has lots of room to grow and improve, and with clear character flaws this time it's easier for Riot to use him in other stories, so that he can have compelling conflicts and grow as a person. I look forward to seeing them explore the emotions that he's most definitely repressing in favor of his facade. Hopefully Riot comes through.

If you look back through my comments, you'll find that I've been very open about my intense hatred of Ezreal because he always felt too mary-sueish. He was naturally good at everything and was cocky and arrogant, but at the same time he saw his legions of fans as annoying? Yet at the same time lets books be written about him? He just annoyed me so much, I couldn't stand him. His gameplay looked fun but I just couldn't like him because he felt like an arrogant jerk who they tried to make not an arrogant jerk who everyone loved. 

I love new Ezreal so much. He's funny, hes dorky, he's awkward, I still don't really support Luxreal but it's more believable now and his reactions around her make him feel so much more human (except in SG Ez, I really dislike his SG lux interactions), and he's just so fun now. He's looking out for himself first and foremost but he also screws things up all the time, makes actual mistakes, and feels a lot more good-natured overall. This rework has made me do a 180 on my Ezreal opinion.

As an Ezreal enthusiast, I definitely agree that he's much more arrogant than I believe he should be. Even with all of the trauma and personal issues he's had I feel like he would be more closed off as a result of these things rather than being rude.

But psychology is a complicated subject to begin with so I'm willing to suspend my disbelief and see what direction he'll take in the future.

For my more in-depth opinion: https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/hGhWpp0E-trueshot-an-ezreal-mains-thoughts-on-the-updates
